p.s: In his speech Johnson emphasizes strongly that he thinks the COP26 is the turning point to stop global warming and that climate change is a very serious problem.
This becomes obvious through his structure of argumentation and his use of rhetorical devices.
The speech is very well structured and shows his intention very easily.
Johnson starts by comparing the audience, the world leaders, to James Bond.
He uses the glorified image of Bond to underline the importance of the leadersleaders' role and creates a picture in their heads, which says that they could become a reallifereal life hero (ll. 1-6).
He also draws a frame by mentioning Bond again in his last sentences.
The possibility of becoming a hero pops up in the head of the audience once more and creates a feeling of euphoria and urgency (ll. 47f).
He continues by describing his own experiences from the Copenhagen and Paris summits which made promises they did not keep (ll. 10-14).
He uses the image of the populationspopulation's anger to move the leaders to actually change something on the COP26 summit (l. 13-15).
Further he quotes that in the last 200 years the industrialized countries did wrong, in order to motivate the leaders to stop climate change (ll. 18-21) and do the right thing according to Johnson.
Then he emphasizes taht they have to work together to invest private sectors (ll. 22-27).
He underlines the importance of those by giving an example of the UK (ll. 27-30).
He also builds up a lot of emotional pressure by including the younger generations and their anger if the leaders fail to stop climate change (ll. 37-42, 44f).
This seems promising because Johnson stated that all of the leaders present are over 60 (l. 33-35), meaning they probably already have children and most likely would not want to ruin their future.
He milds his pressure by repeating that they would have all the necessary technology, ideas, bankers etc. (ll. 16f, 30f, 45f).
Johnson supports his arguments with a lot of rhetorical devices.
It starts in the first sentence where he uses an anaphora (l. 1) to connect the greeting with hsi following comparison.
The comparison contains many metaphoresmetaphors (ll. 4f) and alliteration (l. 3) to create a lively image in the heads of the leaders.
He then connects the comparison with the reality with an antithesis (l. 6f).
The alliteration man-made (l. 8) emphasizes that the humans are fully responsible for global warming.
Then he uses an enumeration (l. 10-12) to make it seem like his experiences stand for the circumstances at every conference.
The quote blah, blah, blah (l. 13) strongly contrasts with his formal speec hand because of that, the quote highlights evenm ore powerful, that the promises are broken very often.
At the same time the quote represents the general public because of the urban formulation, and strongly represents their frustration.
Generally Johnson uses a lot of metaphoresmetaphors to create images.
He uses the images to move to leaders emotionally to urge them into action (ll. 13, 37f, 41, 49, 50).
Additionally he uses many personifications (ll. 13, 18, 21, 23, 26, 28, 42) to empower their intensity and importance.
For example the impatience of the world (l. 13) makes it seem like the whole world and the plant himself is impatient which creates a feeling of importance and urgency.
All in all the speech is very graphic and uses a lot of images.
Also Johnson repeats a lot of words and uses many alliterations and anaphoras (l. 3, 16, 30, 45ff).
The repetition emphasizes their meanings and empowers their importance.
They also stay longer in the audiencesaudience's mindminds.
Johnson uses many climaxes (ll. 22, 30, 37, 44) aswellas well to intensify the meaning of certain phrases, for example COP26 will not and cannot (l. 42).
Especially Johnson uses a variety of different approaches.

He either speaks of himself (ll. 10f) in order to project his feelings on the audience or he approaches the audience or another group to separate him and the audience (ll. 18f), for example I was there with many of you (l. 10) or they will do judge us (ll. 40f).
But mainly he uses inclusive language to create a feeling of intimacy and solidarity, like they all work together and belogn together (ll. 9, 14, 16, 22, 26, 33).
